An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              • Full Article
              • Figures & data

              • Metrics

              • PDF

              ABSTRACT

              ABSTRACT

              Due to the growing importance of professional virtual communities (PVCs) to share professional knowledge in practice, this research proposes an integrated success factor model of PVCs encompassing (1) the componential aspect of a VC system from the operator’s perspective, (2) the knowledge-sharing aspect of a professional community from the members’ perspective, and (3) the VC’s life cycle perspective. An analytical framework was established from theories integrating dimensions from the perspective of operators and members and the virtual community life cycle. To collect and categorize the detailed items of success factors, a systematic literature review and a deductive content analysis were conducted with 64 selected articles. The content analysis results represented the specific perspective of PVCs distinguished from general virtual communities, highlighting factors such as reciprocity, content quality, self-efficacy, and recognition of contributions. Moreover, the inherent patterns in the model contingent to PVC life cycle stages were captured. First, different priorities in the relevant success factor dimensions were identified. Second, the patterns of changing values along with the life- cycle were recognized differently from the operators’ and member’s standpoints. This model can be utilized for the service providers of PVCs in terms of the business and design of PVCs as a strategic management tool and a design guideline.

              1. Introduction

              The rapid development of the Internet and Information and Communication Technology (ICT) has stimulated the proliferation of virtual communities (VCs). Accordingly, the boundaries and dynamics of social interactions of people have been changed considerably, not constrained by time and space, and online social networks have become a natural part of users’ lives (Chang & Chuang, 2011). Moreover, the growth of Web 2.0 tools such as Wikis, social networks, media sharing, media manipulation, blogs, and conversation tools (Conole & Alevizou, 2010) change the way people use the Web allowing them to create and share ‘user-generated content’ (Al-Ghamdi & Al-Ghamdi, 2015). Consequently, the processes of assembling and sharing knowledge, and of re-generating more qualified contents have gained more significance in the era of ‘collective intelligence’ (Pierre, 1997). In line with this trend, more practitioners participate in different kinds of professional virtual communities (PVCs, also called as online professional communities or virtual communities of practice) to improve their expertise and to solve diverse problems in practice (Lin, Hung, & Chen, 2009).

              1.1. The distinctiveness of PVCs

              Scholars have defined a PVC as an extended type of community of practice (Wenger, 1998) or as a virtual community of interest that promotes the sharing of professional experience and expertise beyond traditional organizations (Armstrong & Hagel, 1996; Hiltz, 1985). According to these definitions, PVCs can be positioned at the intersection of VCs and professional communities (i.e., communities of practice, CoP). Hence, PVCs share the basic properties of a VC as a technology-oriented cyberspace based on the connections, communications, and relationship of its members (Lee, Vogel, & Limayem, 2002). Leimeister, Sidiras, and Krcmar (2006) also characterized constitutive elements of a VC such as interacting people, a technical platform, a common purpose, rules of interaction, trust and common identity among members. Whereas professional communities hold different aspects from general communities as scrutinized by Tamjidyamcholo, Bin Baba, Shuib, and Rohani (2014):

              • Members participate in PVCs for solving problems, for obtaining technical knowledge and professional expertise, and for proposing more innovations (Chen & Hung, 2010; Gongla & Rizzuto, 2001)

              • A PVC gathers individuals with common interests, shared expertise and knowledge about a particular area (Hagel, 1999), and they cooperate with each other to achieve common goals (Bressler & Grantham, 2000); and

              • Members in a PVC tend to participate in community activities overtly rather than covertly or anonymously (Klang & Olsson, 1999).

              Considering those specificities, information exchange and knowledge sharing are the critical substance of PVCs that could be directly relevant to community permanence (Hsu, Ju, Yen, & Chang, 2007; Lin et al., 2009). Ridings and Gefen (2004) also specified that information exchange accounts for 53% of reasons for joining in PVCs. Based on such distinctiveness of PVCs, this study clarifies the operationalized definition of PVCs as follows:

              A PVC is a conjoint format of a virtual community and a professional community. As a virtual community, it requires cyberspace as a technical platform and interactions and communications among members with a common purpose and identity. Moreover, as a professional community, it gathers and facilitates individuals in a particular field beyond a conventional organization to share professional knowledge, to exchange their expertise and experience, and to cooperate to achieve common goals.

              Despite the substantial advantage of professional knowledge sharing, it is complicated for PVCs to successfully retain members and to motivate them to exchange their expertise (Ma & Agarwal, 2007). One of the great challenges for PVCs is how to promote knowledge sharing among members because they often lack in the similarities of geopolitical or organizational relationships (Chiu, Hsu, & Wang, 2006). In that sense, it would be worthwhile to investigate how to lead PVCs to a perpetual success, namely to identify the success factors of PVCs.

              1.2. The success factors of PVCs

              Following the aforementioned definition of PVCs, the success factors can be considered in two ways: the factors for successful VCs, and those for successful professional communities. The formers have been investigated globally in the research field of information systems (IS), and the latter mainly in knowledge management (KM) research.

              First, in the IS research, the success factors of VCs—not directly focusing on PVCs—have been examined with a theoretical foundation of DeLone & McLean (D&M) IS Success Model (Delone & McLean, 2003; DeLone & McLean, 1992). The D&M IS Success Model and its successive studies (Chang, Hsu, Hsu, & Cheng, 2014; Gorla, Somers, & Wong, 2010; Lin & Lee, 2006) premise that VCs are one of the representative forms of IS Hence, this stream holds the system perspective toward a VC as a research subject. They measured the success of a VC evaluating the constituent dimensions such as system, information, and service. Those constituent dimensions consequently influenced user satisfaction and continuance intention. The IS success model has been empirically verified with various VCs such as e-commerce (Wang, 2008) or e-learning (Lin, 2007), and one of the venues for verification was the PVC (Hew, 2009; Lin & Lee, 2006). In other words, the research focus has been narrowed from general VCs toward PVCs.

              On the other hand, KM research has focused directly on PVCs since they have emerged as the typical venues in which knowledge management and sharing issues are considered critical with the ICT development. Accordingly, KM researchers have extended their research subjects from off-line professional communities toward on-line ones, namely PVCs (Hara et al., 2006). Particularly, their research focus has been on community members investigating how and why they share knowledge in PVCs (Hung, Lai, & Chou, 2015). Subsequently, many researchers have explored the factors that shape knowledge sharing behaviors, applying various theoretical perspectives such as social cognitive and social capital theories (Chang & Chuang, 2011; Chen & Hung, 2010; Cheung, Lee, & Lee, 2013; Chiu et al., 2006; Lin et al., 2009).

              However, there has been little research that integrates the perspectives of VC system components and a professional community of knowledge sharing. The integrated viewpoint could be coherent with the study of Leimeister et al. (2006), which engendered the stances of both operators and members, because the VC system perspective could be relevant to the operators and the knowledge-sharing perspective to the members. Previous studies on PVCs also lacked the life cycle aspect, which is fundamental to VCs. The perspective of a life cycle could be substantial to determine the success factors for PVCs because those factors have been differentiated according to life cycle stages in the case of general VCs (Iriberri & Leroy, 2009).

              With the research opportunity, therefore, this study aims to propose an integrated success factor model of PVCs incorporating three perspectives: (1) the componential aspect of a VC system from the operator’s perspective, (2) the knowledge sharing aspect of a professional community from the member’s perspective, and (3) the VC’s life cycle perspective. The integrated model could engender the existing divided viewpoints on the successful PVCs, and enable to explore probable interrelations between those viewpoints. According to this aim, the remainder of this article is organized as follows: First, the theoretical foundation to establish an integrated analytical framework is discussed. Second, the description of research methodology to conduct a systematic literature review and a content analysis is followed. Third, the final success factor model of PVCs is presented illustrating meaningful patterns from the content analysis result. The last section discusses implications and limitations of the study as well as future research directions.

              2. Theoretical foundation

              2.1. Componential aspect of a VC system from the operators’ perspective: IS success model

              As previously described, the success factors of VCs from the componential perspective of a community system have been explored on the theoretical basis of DeLone & McLean (D&M) IS Success Model. DeLone and McLean (1992) measured the success of IS by a taxonomy of the system quality as to technical success and the information quality as to semantic success; user satisfaction, IS use, individual impact and organizational impact were included to measure effectiveness. With the evolution of Internet and e-commerce, they proposed an updated D&M IS Success Model (Delone & McLean, 2003) adding a third dimension of ‘service quality’ and combining individual impact and organizational impact into ‘net benefit’. This model has been applied widely in various contexts of Internet-based IS including e-commerce (Cao, Zhang, & Seydel, 2005; Wang, 2008), e-learning system (Lin, 2007; Wang, Wang, & Shee, 2007), and notably VCs (Lin & Lee, 2006) as explained in the introduction. Gorla et al. (2010) also retained this combination of three quality dimensions to examine the relationship between IS quality and organizational impact. Since their proposition of attributes is comprehensive enough to be pertinent to VCs embracing a wide range of previous literature, their specifications were also considered in this study. Table 1 demonstrates the detailed three dimensions in the D&M IS Success Model and its successive studies: system, information, and service.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors

              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1519977
              Published online:
              21 September 2018

              Table 1. Three dimensions of a VC componential aspect from the operator’s perspective.

              CSVDisplay Table

              First, the system quality means the quality of infrastructure, processing, and technical features themselves. In the e-commerce context, the attributes to measure system quality were defined as usability (i.e., ease of use, functionality), availability, reliability, adaptability (i.e., flexibility), and response time (Delone & McLean, 2003). They were adapted for the online community environment by Lin and Lee (2006) as system reliability, convenient access, ease of use and system flexibility. System quality was also specified as system flexibility from the designers’ perspective (e.g., ease of modification by system designer) and system sophistication from the users’ perspective (e.g., user-friendliness, ease of use) (Gorla et al., 2010). Second, the information quality represents the quality of contents and knowledge produced in the IS or VCs. The attributes were commonly identified such as accuracy, timeliness (i.e., up-to-datedness), completeness, relevance, usefulness in terms of information content; consistency, ease of understanding, customized presentation in terms of information format. Last, the service quality, modified from SERVQUAL (Parasuraman, Zeithaml, & Berry, 1988) for the delivery of IS service, embodied the knowledgeable service with courteous interaction (i.e., assurance), the attentive service to users’ specific needs (i.e., empathy), prompt provision of service (i.e., responsiveness), and the punctual delivery and error-free performance (i.e., reliability) (Gorla et al., 2010). Moreover, the aspects of user interface, such as visual design and organization, were added by Lin and Lee (2006) with regard to online community service quality.

              2.2. Knowledge sharing aspect from the members’ perspective: Social cognitive, social capital, and social exchange theories

              One of the biggest challenges in fostering PVCs is the willingness to share knowledge among members (Chiu et al., 2006), and this issue has been explored in KM research investigating how and why the knowledge sharing behaviors are motivated. Accordingly, researchers have identified the significant factors to the knowledge sharing either in a personal or a contextual aspect, and the relevant social theories such as social cognitive theory, social capital theory, and social exchange theory were applied to explicate those factors (Bock, Zmud, Kim, & Lee, 2005; Chang & Chuang, 2011; Cheung et al., 2013; Chiu et al., 2006; Hsu et al., 2007; Kankanhalli, Tan, & Wei, 2005; Lin et al., 2009; Phang, Kankanhalli, & Sabherwal, 2009; Tseng & Kuo, 2010; Wasko & Faraj, 2005).

              The social cognitive theory (Bandura, 1986) is a widely accepted model to validate individual behaviors. It claims that a person’s behavior is influenced and controlled by contextual factors (i.e., the social system) and personal perceptions (e.g., beliefs and expectations) (Wood & Bandura, 1989). Scholars have implemented this theory to investigate individual behaviors in PVCs, namely knowledge sharing, and focused on the role of personal and contextual factors, inducing members’ behavioral consequences (Chen & Hung, 2010; Cheung et al., 2013; Hsu et al., 2007; Lin, 2010; Lin et al., 2009). They classified (1) the facets of individual factors as self-efficacy, perceived relative advantage, and perceived compatibility, and (2) the facets of contextual factors as reciprocity and interpersonal trust. They revised the definition of each facet in accordance with the environments of PVCs as follows:

              • Self-efficacy: the members’ confidence in their skills and capabilities in responding to questions and in providing valuable knowledge;

              • Perceived relative advantage: the perception that knowledge sharing is beneficial to members;

              • Perceived compatibility: the perception that knowledge sharing fit the community values and current needs of members;

              • Reciprocity: the salient beliefs that current knowledge sharing would lead to future request for knowledge being met; and

              • Interpersonal trust: the belief in good intentions, benevolence, competence, and reliability of members with respect to sharing knowledge in PVCs (Chen & Hung, 2010; Lin et al., 2009).

              However, social cognitive theory is limited in explicating the aspect of social network resources retained by individuals and communities and how they influence an individual’s knowledge-sharing behaviors, thus social capital theory was introduced to supplement social cognitive theory (Chiu et al., 2006). Founded on the concepts of structural and relational embeddedness (Granovetter, 1992), Nahapiet and Ghoshal (1998) described social capital using three distinctive dimensions: cognitive (i.e., the resources providing shared representation, interpretations, and systems of meaning among parties), relational (i.e., personal relationships people have developed with each other through a history of interactions), and structural (i.e., the overall pattern of connections between actors). Following the previous literature, Chiu et al. (2006) and Chang and Chuang (2011) adjusted the definition of the three dimensions and their key aspects as follows:

              • Cognitive dimension: the common terms and perspectives which participants understand commonly such as shared language and shared vision;

              • Relational dimension: the nature of interpersonal relations such as trust, reciprocity, and identification (i.e., individual recognition of belonging to a distinct VC from others); and

              • Structural dimension: the impersonal configuration of connections such as the strength and frequency of social interaction tie.

              Moreover, social exchange theory (Blau, 1964) claims that individuals are involved in social exchanges based on an expectation that they will be provided with some form of net benefit (Wasko & Faraj, 2005). Many studies on knowledge sharing have adopted the social exchange theory coupled with social capital theory because social capital theory comprises several important contextual factors in social exchange, such as reciprocity and interpersonal trust (Chen & Hung, 2010; Kankanhalli et al., 2005; Lin, Chiu, Joe, & Tsai, 2010; Wasko & Faraj, 2005). Nevertheless, distinctive factors from social exchange theory—namely, costs and benefits of knowledge sharing—can be underlined. The cost aspect pertains to opportunity costs, such as codification time and effort and the loss of knowledge power, and the benefits aspect includes intrinsic benefits (e.g., self-efficacy, joy of helping others) and extrinsic benefits (e.g., organizational rewards, reciprocity, and reputation) (Ba, Stallaert, & Whinston, 2001; Constant, Sproull, & Kiesler, 1996; Kankanhalli et al., 2005; Wasko & Faraj, 2000). Because the classification of costs and benefits in social exchange theory might not be directly comparable with the dimensions of social cognitive and social capital theories, it was necessary to enhance dimension compatibility for an integrated framework. Consequently, adopting the classification of Pan et al. (2015) (i.e., cognitive factors and social factors), the sub-elements of social exchange theory were re-categorized into cognitive benefits/costs and social benefit, as exhibited in Table 2.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors
              Hyo-Jin Kang http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5266-5379, Jieun Han http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5712-9145 & Gyu Hyun Kwon http://orcid.org/0000-0003-1623-4867
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1519977

              Table 2. Three dimensions of knowledge sharing aspect from the member’s perspective.

              CSVDisplay Table

              Even though the dimensions of social cognitive, social capital, and social exchange theories overlap in part, it was necessary to adjust detailed sub-dimensions to match them properly within each category. Therefore, Table 2 illustrates the matching of dimensions between the three theories and proposes the integrated dimensions to be utilized in this study in the right column. The individual factor construct in social cognitive theory could be comparable to the cognitive dimension or cognitive capital in social capital theory in that both refer to personal perception and cognition. However, self-efficacy and perceived relative advantage can be considered as being headed for an individual self as a target (i.e., confidence in the self’s competencies and the benefits delivered to the self). Meanwhile, compatibility, shared language, and vision can be regarded as being concerned directly with the cognition of PVCs. Consequently, this study re-categorized the sub-aspects of cognitive factors as the perceived individual value and the perceived community value. Likewise, the contextual factor construct of social cognitive theory could be equivalent to the relational dimension of social capital theory involving common subsets such as trust and reciprocity, because they are pertinent to the context of affective relationship development in PVCs. In social exchange theory, social benefits could be considered as individual and relational motivations of social factors (Pan et al., 2015), so they can be comparable to contextual dimensions. Last, the structural dimension was maintained by adopting the original meaning of social connection, network, and interaction ties.

              Table 3 summarizes the two perspectives of operators and members and compares them by criteria to demonstrate how they can compensate each other when integrated. The success of PVCs from the operators’ perspective can be reached with the objective of building a successful PVC, and the consequence can be evaluated by the level of satisfaction, and continuance intention of participants. Whereas, that success from the members’ perspective can be attained with the goal of motivating individuals’ knowledge sharing, and the result can be assessed by the level of knowledge sharing behavior of members. The final terms of dimensions adopted in this study include system (infrastructure), information (knowledge, contents), and service (context, experience) from the operators’ viewpoint; cognitive factors (perceived individual values and perceived community values), social factors (affective relationship development, individual/relational motivations), and structural factors (social connection, network) from the members’ viewpoint.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors

              2.3. The nature of Virtual Communities: Life Cycle Model

              In addition to the success factor dimensions, PVCs share the fundamental properties of VCs by nature as being defined in the Introduction. Generally, a VC evolves in phases and each phase demonstrates diverse aspects and needs (Iriberri & Leroy, 2009). Iriberri and Leroy (2009) proposed a life cycle model of VCs with adopting the five stages in the IS life cycle (Ahituv & Neumann, 1986): inception, creation, growth, maturity, and death. They accentuated the necessity for developers of VCs to understand the different needs of users and managers by life cycle stages. Accordingly, they identified the determinants of stage initiation and classified diverse success factors of VCs through literature review as exhibited in Table 4.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors
              Hyo-Jin Kang http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5266-5379, Jieun Han http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5712-9145 & Gyu Hyun Kwon http://orcid.org/0000-0003-1623-4867
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1519977
              Published online:
              21 September 2018

              Table 4. Life cycle model of virtual communities (excerpted from Iriberri & Leroy, 2009, pp. 13–18).

              CSVDisplay Table

              Regarding the success factors, those of inception stage (i.e., defining a clear purpose and target audience, establishing codes of conduct, building a strong trademark, and defining sources of revenue) could be regarded as the prerequisites to evolve successfully into and initiate the next stage—creation (Malhotra, Gosain, & Hars, 1997; Wenger, McDermott, & Snyder, 2002). That is why the success factors of inception stage overlap with the determinants of stage initiation for the creation stage.

              In the creation stage, system-relevant factors such as user-centered design, interface usability, security and privacy, and reliability of system performance were identified (Andrews, Preece, & Turoff, 2002; Leimeister, Ebner, & Krcmar, 2005). For the success of growth phase, community creators should secure the smooth integration of new members, and the offer of high-quality contents, trust-building elements, and interaction-supporting features (Andrews et al., 2002; Kim, 2000; Zhang & Hiltz, 2003). For the successful maturity phase, creators and operators need to concentrate on the sustainability of community by facilitating the subgroup formation, by delegating control to them, and by rewarding for contributions (Andrews, 2002; Ginsburg & Weisband, 2004).

              In this way, it is noteworthy that the success factors are differentiated because the needs of operators or members and the issues of VCs would vary according to the life cycle stages. In other words, the priorities of critical factors in the inception, creation, growth, or maturity phases would be altered because the conditions of VCs (e.g., the number of members, the scope of interactions, the functions and relations among operators and members) would evolve as the life cycle stages proceed. Nevertheless, the life cycle perspective was attempted to be applied in the situation of general VCs (Iriberri & Leroy, 2009) particularly in the IS research field, but it has scarcely been applied in the situation of PVCs or in the KM research area. Hence, given the lack of research on PVCs from the life cycle viewpoint, it would be worthwhile to incorporate the life cycle model when considering the success factors of PVCs.

              2.4. Establishment of an analytical framework integrating the perspectives of operators and members and the VC Life Cycle

              To integrate those perspectives that have been explored separately in the previous literature, this study proposes the incorporation of three perspectives: the componential aspect of a VC system from the operators’ perspective, the knowledge-sharing aspect of a professional community from the members’ perspective, and the VC’s life cycle perspective, and it establishes a conceptual structure to be utilized as an analytical framework. Accordingly, the six dimensions of the success factors of PVCs and the four stages of the VCs’ life cycle were combined in a cross-table format, as illustrated in Figure 1. This framework will be utilized as a categorization matrix of content analysis.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors

              3. Research methodology

              To develop an integrated success factor model of PVCs, detailed items of success factors needed to be collected and categorized according to the analytical framework. This study chose a systematic literature review method (Petticrew & Roberts, 2008) to use already-published results of extensive empirical or conceptual studies as a source of PVCs’ success factor items. Then, a content analysis was conducted which is an appropriate approach in the literature review to understand patterns of research in a detailed and systematic way (Nakata & Huang, 2005). Particularly, the process adopted in this study, which develops first the analytical framework from theory and then categorizes the data from literature according to the framework, can be defined as a deductive content analysis (Elo & Kyngäs, 2008).

              3.1. Systematic literature review

              The systematic literature review was conducted according to the principles of the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) statement (Moher, Liberati, Tetzlaff, Altman, & The, 2009). No meta-analysis was conducted due to the study design which focused on the selection of appropriate articles for the deductive content analysis. Figure 2 illustrates systematic article selection process from identification, screening, and eligibility to the final inclusion, according to the PRISMA principles.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors
              Hyo-Jin Kang http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5266-5379, Jieun Han http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5712-9145 & Gyu Hyun Kwon http://orcid.org/0000-0003-1623-4867
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1519977
              Published online:
              21 September 2018

              Figure 2. Flow diagram of systematic article selection process.

              Display full size

              Figure 2. Flow diagram of systematic article selection process.

              3.1.1. Data retrieval and filtering

              To include the two different research fields of IS and KM, the following databases were selected: two representative databases of technology and computing science (ACM Digital Library and IEEE Xplore), and three representative databases that include the social sciences as their primary coverage (ScienceDirect, Wiley Online, and Emerald Insight). The search queries were the following keywords—often considered synonyms—in the keyword or abstract field: ‘professional virtual community’, ‘virtual professional community’, ‘professional online community’, ‘online professional community’, or ‘virtual community of practice’. To ensure the relevance of studies, the content types were limited to journal articles and conference proceedings as those types are peer-reviewed. Book chapters were excluded for this reason. Also, only articles written in English were included to ensure the international level of journals or conferences. The publication period was restricted until 2017, but the beginning year was not defined because the initiation of the concept of PVC is usually regarded as the early 2000s.

              3.1.2. Search outcomes and inclusion/exclusion criteria

              From the initial search, 975 articles were retrieved (946 from databases and 29 from additional sources, such as those recommended by peer researchers or by the target database service), and after duplicate articles were removed, the result yielded 937 papers. The list of inclusion criteria was developed to reflect the aims of the literature review, namely the identification of success factors or conditions for PVCs. The titles and abstracts of all the searched articles were screened against the inclusion and exclusion criteria as follows:

              ● Inclusion criteria:

              • Research on the factors/conditions from the componential aspect (system, information, service) in PVCs

              • Research on the factors/conditions from the knowledge-sharing aspect (cognitive factors, social factors, structural factors) in PVCs

              • Research on the success conditions for PVCs

              • Research on the participation or continuous usage of members in PVCs

              • Research on the building and management of PVCs from the operator’s viewpoint

              ● Exclusion criteria:

              • Articles not in English (in some articles, only the abstract and not the full text was written in English)

              • Articles without an abstract

              Through the previous screening of abstracts, 831 articles were excluded, so 106 articles were prepared for the full-text review. Two post-doctoral-level researchers independently reviewed the selected articles with full text against the inclusion criteria, and 42 papers were excluded at this stage. Finally, 64 articles were chosen as the sources of success factor items for the content analysis; among them, 31 were studies in the IS research field and 33 were in the KM field.

              3.2. Deductive content analysis

              During the second screening process with the full text review, 207 success factor items were extracted from 64 articles. The item extraction was conducted by the two researchers: Each half of the article pool was assigned to each researcher to extract success factor items, then they exchanged the item list and the article pool to review the results of their colleague. When discrepancies in the extraction results occurred, they discussed in order to arrive at a reconciliation. Each item was tagged with the source article’s code number, and the success factor data were grouped using the affinity diagram method (Beyer & Holtzblatt, 1999). The code number tagged on each item was counted accumulatively as the data were grouped.

              For deductive content analysis, the two post-doctoral-level researchers conducted the process of classifying the success factor data according to the analytical framework. In a large part of the factor data, it was difficult to distinguish a certain success factor to be pertinent to only one stage of the life cycle because it could be overlapped in multiple phases in terms of relevance. Therefore, the rule to decide the life cycle stage of each factor was settled to classify it to where the factor is considered most influential to the success of a respective phase. Accordingly, the two researchers independently classified each factor according to two axes: (1) one of the six dimensions (i.e., system, information, service, cognitive factors, social factors, and structural factors); and (2) one of the four life cycle stages (i.e., inception, creation, growth, and maturity). The percentage of agreement as inter-coder reliability was calculated as 76.98%. To reach a consensus among the researchers, three rounds of reconciliation process (i.e., abstracting and re-labeling of factor items, adjusting the categorization) were conducted by the two researchers joined by one additional post-doctoral researcher. Finally, the number of success factor items was reduced to 63, classified into 20 sub-categories.

              4. Result & findings

              4.1. Establishment of the integrated success factor model of PVCs

              Figure 3 demonstrates the detailed categorization of success factors as the result of deductive content analysis. The dimensions of operators’ perspective were grouped under the label of ‘Build a successful PVC’, and those of members’ perspective were arranged with the label of ‘Motivate members’ knowledge sharing’. ‘Sourced article #’ is the code of articles from which the factor was extracted, and ‘Freq.’ (i.e., frequency) means the accumulated number of articles which mentioned the respective factor. The success factor in a grey cell is the integrating label of each group, and the frequency in a grey cell is the sum of frequencies in the same group. 63 success factors were divided according to life cycle stages: 6 at the inception, 17 at the creation, 25 at the growth, and 15 at the maturity stage. Figure 4 represents the final integrated success factor model of PVCs which is summarized from Figure 3 with key success factors in each group.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors
              Hyo-Jin Kang http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5266-5379, Jieun Han http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5712-9145 & Gyu Hyun Kwon http://orcid.org/0000-0003-1623-4867
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1519977
              Published online:
              21 September 2018

              Figure 3. Deductive content analysis result.

              Display full size

              Figure 3. Deductive content analysis result.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors
              Hyo-Jin Kang http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5266-5379, Jieun Han http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5712-9145 & Gyu Hyun Kwon http://orcid.org/0000-0003-1623-4867
              https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2018.1519977
              Published online:
              21 September 2018

              Figure 4. Integrated success factor model of professional virtual communities.

              Display full size

              Figure 4. Integrated success factor model of professional virtual communities.

              First, at the inception phase, the goal and purpose of the community, the codes of conduct, and the target user should be clearly defined regarding the service. Additionally, the nature of VCs which is accessible anytime from anyplace would be an inborn system-wise property of a PVC. However, none was identified in the information or in the ‘Motivate’ categories from members’ perspective. Since the inception is the moment before the community members begin to join and participate in a PVC, the members’ perspective or the aspect of information and content might not yet be considered in this phase.

              Second, at the creation phase, the operators need to consider the following factors to build a successful PVC: (1) providing a good level of interface usability, system security and reliability, and technical performance in terms of the system; (2) providing useful contents and having a clear direction for acceptable contents regarding the information; and (3) engaging users in community service development to reflect the needs and preferences of members concerning the service dimension. To motivate members’ knowledge sharing at the cognitive factors level, the users of PVCs need to perceive the value of community in that one’s goal will be achieved (i.e., performance expectation), that the community shares a common language and vision, and that the shared value is compatible with one’s needs. In the context of relationship development, enabling members to have a sense of community and allowing them to identify others’ information and history are the considerable factors. Regarding the structural dimension, enhancing the centrality of internal network, namely the communality of community, is identified as a success factor of the creation stage.

              Third, the expansion of a community size by increasing new memberships is indispensable at the growth phase, thus the highest number of success factors among four phases are required here. From the viewpoint of operators, the system needs to provide technical support for the members’ connection (e.g., a member directory or profiles) and the personalization. Moreover, this phase is where the quality of contents is most critical. Trendy contents on professional skills and expertise need to be updated frequently, and the sources of contents should be prominent enough to be credible and to sustain the high quality. Concerning service, offering support to enable trust building among members (e.g., clear identification of member profiles), maintaining the transparency of service (e.g., trustworthy operations, neutrality of offers), and managing the growth of members (e.g., inducement and integration of new members) are recognized as important for the successful growth stage. To encourage the knowledge sharing of members in this phase, it is essential to make the users perceive the value of knowledge sharing at the individual and utilitarian level such as self-efficacy, individual benefit, and the usefulness for one’s professional development. Moreover, the social factors in the PVC needs to encourage its members to discern reciprocity, interpersonal trust and justice (e.g., respect and fairness in personal interactions), and peer influence. It is consistent with the service dimension in which the value of trust is also emphasized. Concerning the structural factors, enhancing social interaction ties, expanding relationships and connections, and improving the connectivity with external network are considerable factors for the success of PVCs’ growth stage.

              Last, the continuous participation of existing members who have already joined in the PVC is crucial at the maturity phase. For this purpose, the operators need to contemplate how to provide the activity-supporting tools in their community system (e.g., co-work tools, search engine, document sharing tools). Concerning the information dimension, offering a knowledge management stewards who can organize, upgrade, and distribute contents in the PVC could be an effective way for the successful maturity stage. Furthermore, it is crucial to establish a clear reward model to recognize members’ contributions explicitly and to acknowledge their expertise (i.e., recognition of contribution). The subgroups management (i.e., segmenting and supporting the sub-communities of interest) and the distributed delegation (i.e., engaging members to community management to give them authorities) are also considerable factors in the service dimension to induce continuous participation of members. For the enhanced and continuous knowledge sharing among members, the users need to perceive the hedonic value of knowledge sharing such as the enjoyment of helping others, so that they can be willing to share knowledge with active voluntarism. Besides, it could be necessary to foster favorable social factors for establishing one’s reputation (e.g., professional identity, social approval). Feeling altruism and moral obligation to others as the social factors could also be advantageous for the member’s continuous behaviors. Regarding the structural factors, the organizational or domain culture to acknowledge knowledge sharing is a fundamental factor to stimulate those activities constantly at the maturity stage. Additionally, like the knowledge managing steward in the information dimension, a knowledge sharing moderator can be provided to facilitate the exchange of knowledge and communication in a sustained way.

              4.2. Different priorities in the relevant success factor dimensions according to the life cycle stages

              Table 5 represents the frequency of success factors in each dimension by life cycle stage, and the percentage was calculated as the ratio over total frequency in each stage. Figure 5 visualizes the results into the different patterns of priority in the relevant success factor dimensions according to the life cycle stages.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors
              Hyo-Jin Kang http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5266-5379, Jieun Han http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5712-9145 & Gyu Hyun Kwon http://orcid.org/0000-0003-1623-4867

              Figure 5. Different relevance of success factor dimensions in each life cycle stage (Top) and in all life cycle (Bottom).

              Display full size

              Figure 5. Different relevance of success factor dimensions in each life cycle stage (Top) and in all life cycle (Bottom).

              As illustrated in Figure 5, the principal success factor dimension is differentiated with the progress of PVCs’ life cycle: service (e.g., goal and target users) at the inception, system (e.g., infrastructure and usability) at the creation, social factors (e.g., reciprocity and trust) and cognitive factors (e.g., individual-utilitarian values) at the growth, and service (e.g., rewards, subgroups) at the maturity. This implies that the creators or operators of PVCs can concentrate on or prioritize different dimensions according to the life cycle stages. Moreover, those dimensions and factors could work as decisive criteria to judge a PVC’s successful evolution from one phase to the next. Furthermore, during the whole life cycle the service and the social factors are top two dimensions to be considered.

              In terms of two different perspectives of operators and members, the members’ viewpoint (i.e., the sum of cognitive factors, social factors, and structural factors) is more accentuated than the operators’ (i.e., the sum of system, information, and service) particularly at the growth phase, while the standpoint of operators is highlighted more in other phases. That could be because the member growth is the key objective of this stage by attracting and integrating new members (Iriberri & Leroy, 2009). Nevertheless, throughout the all life cycle stages, the operators’ and members’ perspectives are emphasized almost evenly.

              5. Discussion

              5.1. The prioritized factors for the successful PVCs

              This study aimed to establish an integrated success factor model of PVCs, incorporating three perspectives (i.e., the componential aspect from the operator’s perspective, the knowledge-sharing aspect from the members’ perspective, and the VC’s life cycle perspective) through literature review and deductive content analysis. Consequently, the priorities in the relevance of success factor dimensions were identified to be different according to the life cycle stages, such as service at the inception stage, system at the creation, social factors and cognitive factors at the growth, and service at the maturity.

              In addition to this major finding, the content analysis results of the success factors represented the specific perspective of professional VCs distinguished from general VCs. From the results, the primary individual success factors (or values) throughout the life cycle whose frequency was eight or more could be highlighted. When the frequency was eight or more, the number of individual factors was added up by two or three, but it increased radically by nine when the frequency was seven. In other words, it was considered that a threshold of frequency up to eight could maintain the discriminating level to distinguish the factors of top priority. In this way, the primary success factors for PVCs can be listed as follows:

              • Reciprocity (social factors at the growth; freq. = 13);

              • Content quality (information at the growth; freq. = 11);

              • Self-efficacy (cognitive factors at the growth; freq. = 11);

              • Recognition of contributions (service at the maturity; freq. = 11);

              • Interpersonal trust (social factors at the growth; freq. = 10);

              • Interface usability (system at the creation; freq. = 10);

              • Reputation (social factors at the maturity; freq. = 8); and

              • Security and privacy (system at the creation; freq. = 8).

              Given that the inherent purpose of PVCs is the exchange of professional knowledge, reciprocity that current knowledge sharing can ensure future feedback on one’s request was the most substantial factor with the highest frequency. This is also supported by Chang and Chuang (2011) and Sedighi, Splunter, Brazier, Beers, and Lukosch (2016) in that reciprocity is essential because it influences both the quantity and quality of participation in knowledge sharing. Moreover, the expectation of reciprocal knowledge exchange works as a principal driver to encourage the attitude of participants toward knowledge sharing (Bock et al., 2005). For instance, the request for additional information or professional contributions of a certain quality before reading or using other professionals’ knowledge could be a function that structuralizes reciprocity into a PVC service.

              The factors with the second-highest frequency were the content quality, self-efficacy, and recognition of contribution. High-quality content that secures the usefulness and appropriateness for the professional domain, as well as the—self-evaluated—high quality of individual members’ competency (i.e., self-efficacy) were also considered critical for the success of PVCs. In other words, the assured high quality of contents and members would be vital to gather and retain professional members and to encourage their continuous participation (Jin, Cheung, Lee, & Chen, 2009; Tamjidyamcholo, Bin Baba, Tamjid, & Gholipour, 2013). Increasing the eligibility of content or member quality by indicating the level of recommendation or evaluation from other members could be an exemplary direction for these issues.

              Furthermore, the recognition of contribution is to provide explicit rewards to acknowledge members’ contributions according to the level of contributions. For this, it could be important for PVCs to provide services relevant to reward models that can visualize the level of contributions and recognize professional identities and expertise. These kinds of services can respond to the desire for self-actualization (e.g., formal expert status and informal recognition by contributions to the community) (Ardichvili, Page, & Wentling, 2002). Typically, the members of a PVC do not belong to the same organization, so a pecuniary reward system could not work here. Instead, other forms of explicit reward models such as a mileage or score system or an authority system contingent upon one’s contribution levels might be alternative examples.

              Additionally, interpersonal trust was the fundamental value to be assured considering the professional characteristics of sharing, such as about contents (i.e., professional knowledge), persons to share with, or spaces in which the sharing occurs. Interpersonal trust can also be considered identification-based trust (Tamjidyamcholo et al., 2013) in that it requires a reciprocal understanding of the premise. In that sense, interpersonal trust could be a fundamental condition for the factor of top priority, namely, the reciprocity. Also, reputation was identified as an important factor for PVCs. Accordingly, a reputation management system that can support community members to express professional status, social approval, or respect for other experts (Liao, To, & Hsu, 2013) would leverage individuals to achieve status in the community and to be motivated for active participation.

              Meanwhile, the success factors which might be considered for general VCs, such as interface usability and security and privacy, were also highly ranked for PVCs. However, given that a PVC is also a specialized form of a VC, it is expected that a PVC shares foundational factors with a VC, especially in terms of system level at the creation phase. Aside from the creation-phase factors, the other accentuated factors can be regarded as highly explicable for PVCs, principally focusing on the factors of growth and maturity phases, and half of them from the social factors dimension (i.e., reciprocity, interpersonal trust, and reputation).

              5.2. The different patterns of changing values along with the PVC life cycle

              The highlighted values also changed as the life cycle proceeded, in both the operators’ and members’ standpoints differently. In the operators’ perspective, the value of clarity was emphasized first at the inception, such as the clarity of the community goal, target user, and identity. At the creation, the usability (of the system) and usefulness (of the contents) were the principal values that could ensure the fundamental and functional purpose of a PVC as a community system of knowledge exchange. Afterward, the growth stage accentuated the values of trust and transparency, so the credibility of contents, the support for interpersonal trust building, and the transparent service emerged as important. Lastly, the recognition was the primary value to be enhanced at the maturity in any form of intrinsic or extrinsic reward. This pattern of value evolution (i.e., (1) clarity, (2) usability and usefulness, (3) trust and transparency, and (4) recognition) is consistent with the findings of Iriberri and Leroy (2009), although their study covered only the IS research from the operator’s perspective.

              From the members’ perspective, on the other hand, individual participants need to be encouraged to perceive (i.e., cognitive factors) different values according to life cycle stages. Exchanging professional knowledge has a functional and utilitarian value. Therefore, an individual will join a PVC only if the common vision and language of the community that shares similar domain knowledge coincide with the person’s needs (i.e., compatibility), and this is why the perceived community value was identified first at the creation stage. After that, the individual benefits needed to be clearly satisfied (i.e., utilitarian value) at the growth phase. Moreover, the values of trust, justice, and reciprocity, which are indispensable for sharing knowledge at the professional level, were also emphasized for the successful growth phase. After these values are fulfilled, what stimulates sustained participation during the maturity stage are the hedonic and affective values in social relationships, such as enjoyment, altruism, or social obligation. This pattern of changing values from the members’ viewpoint (i.e., (1) perceived community values, (2) perceived individual-utilitarian values, and (3) perceived individual-hedonic values) could be utilized as classifying criteria to distinguish diverse elements to enhance knowledge sharing depending on the life cycle stages.

              5.3. Academic contributions and implications for future research

              The unique contribution of this study to IS and KM research is the proposal of an integrated viewpoint to organize the success factor model focused on PVCs, combining the VC’s componential aspect, knowledge-sharing aspect, and life cycle aspect. Hence, the originality of this model lies in the integration of operators’ and members’ perspectives, which enables the understanding of the success factors of PVCs comprehensively without missing or weighting any viewpoints of two principal stakeholders. In other words, this model enables the comprehension of the success factors of PVCs in a multi-dimensional way, namely from both of two principal stakeholders’ standpoints, and from different life cycle perspectives. Therefore, the individual factors of top priority particular to the successful PVCs were drawn from the model. Furthermore, it would be worthwhile to capture the inherent patterns in the model contingent to PVC life cycle stages: the different priorities in the relevant success factor dimensions and the different patterns of changing values along with the life cycle.

              Founded on the integrated success factor model of PVCs, various research directions could be initiated, as exemplified in Table 6. First, the association among success factor dimensions or individual factors can be studied such as, for instance, the investigations associating the system and service to enhance trust building or exploring the relationship between reciprocity and the degree of trust. Second, the comparative studies of relevant dimensions or success factors can be conducted according to the different types of PVCs, for example, by professional domains, by national culture, by organizational culture, or by social network. Third, the scale development of measurement items for success factor dimensions can be carried out. Based on the measurement set, a diagnostic checklist or a toolkit could be established to support the management and improvement of PVCs. Fourth, researches that examine empirically the validity of theoretical model can be possible, either quantitatively or qualitatively. The empirical validation can be attempted through social network analysis, for instance, to identify the relation between social network parameters and PVC values or to investigate the social network patterns (Hayat, Lesser, & Samuel-Azran, 2017). Last, the perspective of life cycle can be further investigated by subdividing the life cycle phases in detail or by identifying multiple phases pertinent to each success factor. In this way, this study can additionally find its academic contribution by implying diverse future research topics on PVCs based on this success factor model.

              An Integrated Success Factor Model of Professional Virtual Communities: Incorporation of the Operators, Members, and Life Cycle Perspectives

              All authors

              Published online:

              Table 6. Potential topics for future research based on the success factor model of professional virtual communities.

              5.4. Practical implications for the management and design of PVCs

              For the creators or operators of PVCs in practice, the success factor model of PVCs can be utilized as (1) a diagnostic and strategic tool to enhance the business and management values, and (2) a design guideline to support the effective development of PVCs’ systems and service platforms.

              In terms of the management of PVCs, first, the model can be applied as a checklist to diagnose the status of a PVC. It could help to identify which factor is already involved or not in their PVC and what would be the probable causes of current good or poor results of community progress. Second, it can be referred to as a decision guide for strategy and action plans, advising the priorities of development in the current or future stage. The community creators or operators are often required to select and focus their limited resources, and this model can assist with the strategic decisions to prioritize development requirements.

              Regarding the design of PVCs, the model can serve as a guideline to develop the system and service platform of a PVC. It could support the design planning regarding what kind of services and functions should be designed in which stages of the life cycle. It could also suggest the development direction when designing a system structure, such as functional hierarchy or information architecture, or designing a specific function or content. For instance, with relation to the prioritized success factors from Section 5.1, several practical directions according to life cycle stages can be suggested as follows:

              ● Creation phase

              • High standard of interface usability

              • Clear assurance of security and privacy of system

              ● Growth phase

              • Reciprocity: the request for additional information or professional contributions of a certain quality before reading or using other professionals’ knowledge

              • Content quality: the indication of the level of recommendation or evaluation from other members to increase the eligibility of content or member quality

              ● Maturity phase

              • Recognition of contribution: explicit reward models such as a mileage, score system or an authority system contingent upon one’s contribution levels

              • Reputation: reputation management system that can support community members to express professional status, social approval, or respect for other experts

              Moreover, the integrated perspective of operators and members could enforce the user-centered aspect of the design direction. Further extending the implication boundary, the integrated success factor model of PVCs could work as a design reference not only for a VC but also for a mobile application and service platform for professionals.

              6. Conclusion

              Due to the increasing significance of PVCs for sharing professional knowledge and solving diverse problems in practice, this research suggested the integrated success factor model of PVCs. By incorporating three perspectives which is the original contribution of this study (i.e., the componential aspect from the operators’ perspective, the knowledge sharing aspect from the members’ perspective, and the VC’s life cycle perspective), the initial model was established through literature review and the enhanced model was completed by deductive content analysis. The priorities in the relevance of success factor dimensions were identified to be different according to the life cycle stages (i.e., service at the inception, system at the creation, social factors and cognitive factors at the growth, and service at the maturity). Moreover, the high-priority success factors particular to PVCs were underlined including reciprocity, content quality, self-efficacy, and recognition of contributions. Furthermore, the patterns of changing values contingent to the life cycle were captured differently from the operators’ standpoint (i.e., (1) clarity, (2) usability and usefulness, (3) trust and transparency, and (4) recognition) and from the members’ viewpoint (i.e., (1) perceived community values, (2) perceived individual-utilitarian values, and (3) perceived individual-hedonic values).

              Despite the contributions from those findings, this study still has limitations stemming from the process of developing the integrated success factor model for PVCs. First, as previously mentioned in the methodology section, the life cycle phase of a success factor was categorized to where the factor is regarded as most influential even though the factor could be relevant to multiple phases. Consequently, this model could be restricted to listing all the pertinent factors in a certain stage, but it is more appropriate to illustrate the representative success factors. Second, the model was established from the perspective of the general form of PVCs; hence, the specificity of domains or practice fields of PVCs was not included in this model. To complement this weakness, therefore, a comparative study with various types of PVCs could be possible, as described in the academic implications for future research (see Table 6), such as the different types by professional domains, national cultures, organizational cultures, or social network. This complementary study could also be valuable to test the applicability of the model that was developed from the literature with validation from real cases.

              The sophisticated mapping of life cycle stages

              • Detailed categorization of life cycle stages


              e.g., A success factor model for the PVCs according to the evolution of membership size

              • Multi-stage association of success factors


              e.g., Identification of the importance of trust in PVCs according to their life cycles

              Additional information

              Author information

              Hyo-Jin Kang

              Hyo-Jin Kang She is an assistant professor of the Department of Service Design Engineering at Sungshin Women’s University. She holds a BS and a PhD degree in industrial design from KAIST (KR), and an MBA from Sorbonne-Dauphine-Renault (FR), and was a research professor at Hanyang University. Her research interests pertain to UX and service design including virtual environments with smart technology.

              Jieun Han

              Jieun Han She is a research professor at Imagine X lab at Hanyang University, and she holds a BS and a PhD degree in interior architecture design at the same school. Even though her academic interests initially start from physical environment, now she is trying to connect her findings to virtual environment with advanced technology.

              Gyu Hyun Kwon

              Gyu Hyun Kwon He is an assistant professor of the graduate school of technology and innovation management at Hanyang University. He is also jointly appointed at the department of art and technology. He is majorly working in the field of cognitive engineering and entrepreneurship and co-directing the Imagine X lab.

              Funding

              This work was supported by the Ministry of Education of the Republic of Korea and the National Research Foundation of Korea under Grant NRF-2017S1A5A8019275. This fund has no specific role or influence in the research process.
